head.title: Effects of Moisture-Proof Back Passivation Layers of Al2O3 and AlxTi1–xOy Films on Efficiency Improvement and Color Modulation in Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Effects of Moisture-Proof Back Passivation Layers of Al2O3 and AlxTi1–xOy Films on Efficiency Improvement and Color Modulation in Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells

In this study, the back passivation layers (BPLs) were developed to protect hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin films of transparent solar cells from humidity and contaminants. Metal oxide compound films with Al (Al2O3) and Ti (AlxTiyOz (ATO)) were fabricated by plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition for the BPLs on transparent solar cells. The BPLs of Al2O3 films applied to the transparent solar cells were deposited in different thicknesses to evaluate the performance, and the ATO film thickness was fixed at 30 nm. Even at the thinnest thickness of 30 nm, the water vapor transmission rates of BPLs were very low at 1.96 × 10–3 (Al2O3) and 1.23 × 10–2 g/m2·day (ATO). In addition to moisture protection, measures of cell performance, including open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current density, were improved by blocking the leakage current and through the optical interference effects of the BPLs. The solar cell with ATO BPLs exhibited an increase in efficiency of more than 12% compared with those of conventional reference cells. Furthermore, by varying the refractive index and thickness of the BPLs, the reflection and transmission spectra were modulated to implement various cell colors without serious loss in cell efficiency.

div.p:
In this study, the back passivation layers (BPLs) were developed to protect hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin films of transparent solar cells from humidity and contaminants. Metal oxide compound films with Al (Al
2
O
3
) and Ti (Al
x
Ti
y
O
z
(ATO)) were fabricated by plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition for the BPLs on transparent solar cells. The BPLs of Al
2
O
3
films applied to the transparent solar cells were deposited in different thicknesses to evaluate the performance, and the ATO film thickness was fixed at 30 nm. Even at the thinnest thickness of 30 nm, the water vapor transmission rates of BPLs were very low at 1.96 × 10
–3
(Al
2
O
3
) and 1.23 × 10
–2
g/m
2
·day (ATO). In addition to moisture protection, measures of cell performance, including open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current density, were improved by blocking the leakage current and through the optical interference effects of the BPLs. The solar cell with ATO BPLs exhibited an increase in efficiency of more than 12% compared with those of conventional reference cells. Furthermore, by varying the refractive index and thickness of the BPLs, the reflection and transmission spectra were modulated to implement various cell colors without serious loss in cell efficiency.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
To mitigate the potential environmental destruction caused by climate change, it is necessary to increase the influence and status of renewable energy.
(1−3)
Because electricity is produced and consumed in the same building using building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) systems, one method for expanding the use of renewable energy is to explore these systems that neither require additional land nor exhibit electricity transmission losses.
(4,5)
Recently, the market for BIPVs has been expanding and various types of BIPVs, such as tiles, roofs, and solar windows, have been actively researched and developed.
(6−8)
Among them, the commercialization of solar windows has diminished owing to practical difficulties in its technology, such as manufacturing a uniform module in a large area and satisfying strict window specifications for stability and durability. Nevertheless, in modern architecture, the use of solar windows in buildings tends to be on the rise because of the growing demand for wider windows in buildings.
(9)
Conventional transparent solar windows comprise both transparent and opaque parts,
(10)
where the opaque parts alone can generate electric power, thus limiting visibility. Accordingly, full penetration (FP)-type transparent solar cells are desirable for solar windows because they permit light to be transmitted through the entire area of the cells and windows.
(11)

Research is ongoing on transparent solar cells made of various materials, including dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), organic photovoltaics (OPVs), perovskite solar cells (PSCs), and amorphous-based in organic systems.
(12,13)
Although organic-based solar cells such as DSSCs, OPVs, and PSCs are expected to be manufactured at low costs, they are difficult to commercialize because of their poor durability, poor stability, and the tendency toward degradation of efficiency when fabricated in large-area substrates.
(14−16)
However, hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells are suitable for transparent solar windows because they have already demonstrated outstanding performance in the field of thin-film solar windows, with properties such as excellent stability, high durability, and lack of a mass production barrier.
(17,18)

To harmonize BIPV windows with the building and meet aesthetic demands, color implementation technology is required. Thus far, various photovoltaics have implemented colors, albeit at the cost of a large deviation in cell efficiency. However, we demonstrated that ultrathin transparent multilayered electrodes (TMEs) exhibit low sheet resistance (as low as 7 Ω/square) and can display various colors.
(11,17,19)
The colors were achieved without varying the conditions of the light-absorbing layer; thus, the efficiency variation was narrowly maintained despite the color difference.

One of the important characteristics of a-Si:H cells is durability because their physical properties are very stable, unlike those of organic-based materials. However, the standard specification of building regulations is strict for the window construction market, such that the thin-film a-Si:H solar cells are still required to meet the high moisture-proof requirement. The front of the a-Si:H cell can be protected by the substrate glass; however, for long-term stability, its reverse side requires a reliable passivation layer to protect its transparent electrodes and absorbers from moisture and contaminant penetration.

Recently, inorganic thin films such as SiN
x
and Al
2
O
3
having similar water vapor transmittance rate (WVTR) values are used as moisture permeation barrier layers for OLEDs or organic solar cells.
(20,21)
Metal oxide compounds are commonly used on back-side electrodes of transparent thin-film solar cells. Additionally, the water-proofing capability of aluminum oxide (Al
2
O
3
) films is excellent when the films are grown by atomic layer deposition (ALD).
(22)
The thin films deposited by plasma-enhanced ALD (PEALD) with sequential and self-limiting characteristics can structurally minimize pinholes and defects that provide a penetration path of gases such as water molecules.
(20,23)
In addition, the chemical stability and passivation effect requiring high-density films were demonstrated by the ALD process at high temperatures in the previous reports;
(24)
in the ALD process, the higher the temperature, the higher the density of the film, which improves the chemical stability of the Al
2
O
3
film. Therefore, the high density and outstanding chemical stability of Al
2
O
3
films made using ALD are effective in preventing the diffusion of water molecules. Moreover, the ALD growth method allows for precise control of the optical thickness in terms of both the physical thickness and chemical composition, which can change the transmission and reflection spectra of thin-film solar cells via optical interference. Therefore, more diverse colors and detailed color controls can be achieved by adjusting the optical thicknesses of the passivation layers.

In this study, we present reliable and functional back passivation layers (BPLs) of transparent a-Si:H solar cells for BIPV windows. Using a supercycle concept in PEALD to adjust the chemical composition,
(25)
the BPLs are composed of Al
2
O
3
and Al
x
Ti
y
O
z
(ATO), whose refractive indices vary with the addition of Ti to Al
2
O
3
. ATO was researched not only because of its transmittance but also because of its color implementation to meet the aesthetic requirements of the architectural appearance. The supercycle concept enables material engineering of the optical thickness through control of the refractive index and physical thickness. Controlling optical thickness affects the transmission and reflection colors of the cells via optical interference and allows the exploration of the optical effects of Al
2
O
3
and ATO BPLs. Besides, the effects of BPLs on cell performance and efficiency were also investigated. The fabrication of these BPLs can be used as a new method to improve the optical and electrical performance of transparent solar cells.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Transparent full penetration-type hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells were fabricated with the structure shown in
Figure
1
. The front transparent conductive electrodes (TCEs) were ZnO/Ga (GZO) films deposited by a sputtering method at 200 °C on the glass with textured fluorine-doped tin oxide (600 nm). During the fabrication of the a-Si:H solar cells, all deposition steps for growing p-, i-, and n-layers proceeded in a single chamber using PECVD at 200 °C, and the deposition conditions were identical to those in our previous reports.
(11−19)
The p-layer of the as-fabricated solar cells consisted of a double layer of hydrogenated microcrystalline Si (μc-Si:H, 11 nm) and amorphous silicon carbide (a-SiC:H, 5 nm), which provided sufficient width and high band gap for the depletion region and p-layer, respectively. The thickness of the i-a-Si:H layer was set at 200 nm to ensure high transparency. The transparent multilayered electrodes (TME) comprising GZO and thin Ag films were grown by the sputtering method, while the TME with GZO/Ag/GZO structures was prepared in situ by sputtering multitargets of GZO and Ag. When the structure of the TME was varied, its conductivity and reflectance could be optimized for applications in transparent solar cells.
(17,19)

div.p: Figure 1. Structure of transparent a-Si:H solar cells employing the BPL.

div.div:
The BPLs of Al
2
O
3
and ATO with different optical thicknesses were deposited on the TME of the cells. As a BPL is an insulator with low conductivity, as shown in
Table S1
, it was deposited after taping a small area of TME to connect with the probe tip during subsequent measurement. The Al
2
O
3
and ATO films were grown by PEALD at 150 °C using precursors of trimethylaluminum (TMA) for Al and titanium tetra-isopropoxide for Ti, respectively, including oxygen gas with plasma, which acted as a reactant gas. The ATO film controlled the material properties of the BPL by controlling the amount of Ti added to Al
2
O
3
. The ATO films were fabricated by the supercycle method, which consists of various combinations of Al
2
O
3
and TiO
2
subcycles. Namely, the supercycle of ATO formation included n subcycles of Al
2
O
3
and m subcycles of TiO
2
. This supercycle was denoted as ATO (n, m). The chemical composition of the BPL depends on the configured number of supercycles; therefore, controlling the optical thickness of the BPL is possible by adjusting the number of supercycles.
Figure S1
shows a cycle of Al
2
O
3
formation and a supercycle of ATO formation. The Al and Ti contents were controlled by varying the cycle coordinates. In the present study, ATO (1,1), ATO (2,1), and ATO (3,1) thin films obtained by increasing the number of subcycles of the Al
2
O
3
process were applied as BPLs of transparent a-Si:H solar cells.

The WVTR was measured for the back passivation Al
2
O
3
and TiO
2
films with a thickness of 30 nm, which were deposited on a polyethylene naphthalate substrate (∼50 cm
2
) at 100 °C via plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition (PEALD). The WVTR of the sample was measured using a MOCON Deltaperm system (Technolox Ltd). The Deltaperm system used the total pressure method for measuring the rate of permeation as explained in standard JIS K-7129A for water vapor. To confirm the moisture resistance effect of BPLs, a constant temperature–humidity test was conducted for 100 h in an environment of 85 °C and 85% relative humidity (RH) by PR-3KP made by ESPEC. The reflection and transmission spectra were measured by ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy in the wavelength range of 380–780 nm. For an illuminated current density (
J
)–voltage (
V
) analysis, a solar simulator at AM 1.5 was used at room temperature (∼25 °C), and the measured area of the electrode was 0.25 cm
2
. To measure quantum efficiency, an IQE-200 measurement system was used. The color coordinates of the transparent a-Si solar cells used for the optical thickness variations of the BPLs were measured using a spectrophotometer (CM-3700d, Minolta) with a 10° standard observer under the D65 illuminant. The refractive index and film thickness were measured by ellipsometry.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
3.1. WVTR of Al
2
O
3
, TiO
2
, and ATO (3,1) Films and Long-Term Stability of Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells
div.div:
The moisture-proof test has been performed in a chamber at 40 °C and 90% RH to determine the WVTR of Al
2
O
3
, TiO
2
, and ATO films deposited at 100 °C. The results of WVTR measurements are listed in
Table
1
. The WVTR values of the Al
2
O
3
and TiO
2
films were 1.96 × 10
–3
and 1.02 × 10
–2
g/m
2
·day, respectively. It was reported that OPVs can be protected by a 100–200 μm-thick medium barrier material with a WVTR of around 10
–3
g/m
2
·day.
(26)
Table
1
shows excellent WVTR values of the Al
2
O
3
and TiO
2
films for a very thin thickness of 30 nm. As expected, the water-proof ability of the Al
2
O
3
films was better than that of the TiO
2
films. Besides, the WVTR of the 30 nm ATO (3,1) film was 1.23 × 10
–2
g/m
2
·day, which implies that ATO films may serve as better protective layers than TiO
2
films.

Table 1. WVTR Values of Al
2
O
3
, TiO
2
, and ATO (3,1) on the PEN Substrate

Therefore, Al
2
O
3
and ATO with low WVTR values were applied to solar cells as the BPL to prevent moisture permeation.
Figure
2
shows how the efficiency of transparent a-Si:H solar cells with and without BPLs varies under three different stressed conditions, immediately after sample preparation, after 1 year in the air, and after exposure to constant 85 °C with 85% RH for 100 h. The test of constant temperature and humidity was conducted using solar cells exposed to the external environment for 1 year. The solar cell without BPL decreased by 32% after 1 year in the atmosphere, but the efficiency of the solar cell applied with Al
2
O
3
30 nm and ATO 30 nm decreased by 4 and 11%, respectively. This result indicates that the BPL played an excellent role in maintaining long-term stability.

div.p: Figure 2. Solar cell efficiency changes for 1 year under atmospheric (room temperature) conditions and 100 h under high temperature/high humidity conditions (at 85 °C/85% RH).

div.h3:
3.2. Electrical Characteristics of Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells Employing BPLs of Various Al
2
O
3
Thicknesses
div.div:
The performances of the solar cells with BPLs used for different thicknesses are compared in
Table
2
, in which we adopt the figure of merit (FoM), the product of power conversion efficiency, and average transmittance to evaluate the transmittance and efficiency of the transparent solar cells.
(17,19)
In
Table
2
, sample R is the reference solar cell fabricated without a BPL layer and is used to compare the cell performances with those of other samples. All solar cells A–D with the Al
2
O
3
passivation layers exhibited a higher open circuit voltage (
V
OC
) and higher short circuit current density (
J
SC
) than the reference sample R; sample D, with a 70 nm-thick Al
2
O
3
film, exhibited the best FoM. When BPLs were employed behind the cells, the leakage current in the charge collection process potentially reduced, resulting in enhanced
J
SC
and
V
OC
values, owing to the increase in shunt resistance. When BPLs were deposited, the insulating properties of the BPL were thought to passivate unwanted leakage paths that occurred randomly during cell fabrication. As a similar effect, a reduction in shunt resistance occurred when a highly resistive film was employed on the rear side before the deposition of the rear electrode in a-Si:H solar cells.
(28)
The illuminated
J
–
V
curves and external quantum efficiency (EQE) are shown in
Figure
2
a for different Al
2
O
3
BPL thicknesses. When using BPL, the EQE in the short-wavelength range of 400–550 nm is higher than that of the reference, as shown in
Figure S2a
. However, we note that the EQE values in the short-wavelength region are generally improved for the reference cell owing to the reduction in leakage current, whereas the EQE values in the long-wavelength region exhibit more complicated behaviors because the EQE values also depend on the optical interference of the BPLs. However, considering that the color of the transparent cell can be defined as the reflective response in the long-wavelength region, the small variation of EQE in the long-wavelength region implies that the cell efficiency is not significantly changed by the BPL conditions. This is a favorable feature for adjusting the color of the cells for BIPV windows.

Table 2. Performance Parameters of Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells with Various Thicknesses of Al
2
O
3
BPLs

div.h3: 3.3. Electrical Characteristics of Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells Employing BPLs with Various ATO Composition Rates
div.div:
Figure
3
b shows the illuminated
J
–
V
and EQE curves for the different compositions of the BPL at a thickness of 30 nm according to the combination of a supercycle. From the WVTR results for the films, a BPL thickness of 30 nm is expected to be sufficient for preventing the ingress of moisture. In
Table
4
, the performance parameters of the solar cells employing BPLs are listed and compared for different compositions of the BPLs. Among the samples, sample G with the ATO (3,1) film showed the best performance; the highest values were obtained for
V
OC
(0.881 V),
J
SC
(11.84 mA/cm
2
), FoM (130.8), and efficiency (6.64%). The results in
Table
3
show that efficiency can be improved without serious optical loss. In
Figure S2b
, the sample with ATO (3,1) is shown to exhibit lightly improved EQE in the long-wavelength range (550–700 nm). Similar to the application of Al
2
O
3
to solar cells, this improvement can be attributed to the reduction in leakage current caused by the employment of BPLs.

div.p:
Figure 3. Characteristics of the transparent a-Si:H solar cells with various passivation layers under the AM 1.5G illumination condition; current-density–voltage (
J
–
V
) curves of the a-Si:H solar cells (a) with various Al
2
O
3
layer thicknesses and (b) with various ATO Ti contents.

div.div:
Table 3. Performance Parameters of Transparent a-Si:H Solar Cells with 30 nm-Thick Al
2
O
3
and ATO BPLs

The refractive index of the Al
2
O
3
-based BPL (ATO) can be changed by adjusting the chemical composition of Ti, such that the refractive indices of ATO (1,1), ATO (2,1), and ATO (3,1) are 1.80, 1.77, and 1.71, respectively, as shown in
Table
4
; as the ratio of the subcycle for TiO
2
increases, the refractive index of the ATO film becomes close to the refractive index value of TiO
2
. In our transparent solar cell structure, the optical interference occurs in the optical structure of the TME and BPL, and the transmittance spectra and the reflectance on the BPL surface can be changed according to the optical thickness of the BPL (the product of the refractive index and physical thickness of a film).
Table 4. Refractive Indices of the BPLs with Different Ti Contents

Figure
4
shows the transmission and reflectance spectra of the a-Si:H solar cells under different conditions of BPLs. Although the BPL is additionally employed, the transmittance of the solar cells is not seriously degraded at a visible wavelength (380–780 nm). The transmittance difference observed in the long-wavelength range (greater than 700 nm) is mainly due to the difference in the optical thickness of the BPLs. The interference altering the transmittance and reflectance of the solar cell can be observed in the long-wavelength region where the solar cells cannot absorb light. In
Figure
4
, it can be seen that the transmittance and reflectance spectra change significantly when changing the thickness of Al
2
O
3
. When changing the refractive index of the BPL, the central wavelength of the reflectance can be gradually changed without significantly changing the overall transmittance. These changes in spectral response caused by the BPL can be used as a strategy to implement various colors of the transparent solar cells because the variation in efficiency is not sufficient to trigger a change in the composition of the BPL, as given in
Table
3
.

div.p: Figure 4. (a) Transmittance and (b), (c) reflectance spectra of transparent a-Si:H solar cells employing BPLs with various optical thicknesses.

div.div:
For a given structure of TME, in which the thickness of GZO/Ag/GZO is 500/12/50 nm, the effect of optical interference of BPLs on the variation of colors, which can be seen by the observer of the building, was investigated. In
Figure
5
, the observed color and color coordinates on the x–y chromaticity chart are presented for the BPL of the transparent solar cells. The color of the reference cell was dark red, and it changed to blue-green and then orange as the Al
2
O
3
BPL was employed, with its thickness increasing from 30 to 70 nm. As shown in
Figure
5
i, the red asterisks representing the color coordinates of the samples with Al
2
O
3
films show a linearly wide locus on the chart; both the x and y coordinates increase with the thickness of the BPL. However, the color coordinates of the samples with ATO BPLs exhibit a circular trajectory for the change in refractive index. Therefore, the patterns of the color variation can be selected according to the control method, varying the thickness and refractive index of the BPL.

div.p:
Figure 5. Photographs of transparent a-Si:H solar cells showing color variations: (a) reference (R), (b) Al
2
O
3
30 nm (A), (c) Al
2
O
3
50 nm (B), (d) Al
2
O
3
70 nm (C), (e) Al
2
O
3
110 nm (D), (f) ATO (1,1) 30 nm (E), (g) ATO (2,1) 30 nm (F), and (h) ATO (3,1) 30 nm (G); (i) measured color coordinates of the transparent solar cells on the
x
-
y
-chromaticity chart.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this study, BPLs were developed to protect transparent a-Si:H solar cells from ambient humidity and contaminants. The Al
2
O
3
and ATO films grown by PEALD exhibited excellent water-proof properties with a WVTR value of less than 1.23 × 10
–2
g/m
2
·day even at a thickness of 30 nm. In addition, the solar cell with Al
2
O
3
or ATO BPLs exhibited improved
V
OC
and
J
SC
than that of the reference cell irrespective of the thickness of the BPLs. Furthermore, cell efficiency was enhanced using various compositions of ATO films as the BPL. The EQE measurements demonstrated improvements at both short and long wavelengths, which implies an enhancement in both the internal field and optical interference. Although the thin film was added to the solar cells, the transmittance at the range of visible light was not significantly decreased. For aesthetic solar windows, various colors were implemented by adjusting both the thickness and refractive index of BPLs. The colors change in a different way according to the method of varying thickness and that of varying refractive index. Thus, the adoption of BPLs is beneficial not only for preventing the invasion of moisture but also for enhancing cell efficiency and implementing various colors, in addition to satisfying aesthetic requirements and providing additional value to solar windows.

Amorphous single-junction cells for vertical BIPV application with high bifaciality
Reininghaus, Nies; Feser, Clemens; Hanke, Benedikt; Vehse, Martin; Agert, Carsten

Solar cells used in building integration of photovoltaic cells (BIPV) are commonly made from cryst. wafer cells. This contribution investigates the challenges and benefits of using bifacial solar cells in vertical installations. We show that those cells get up to 13% more irradiance compared to optimum tilted south facing monofacial modules in Germany. The role of the n-layer in thin amorphous bifacial single-junction cells intended to be used as bifacial cells in BIPV applications is investigated. In contrast to the superstrate cell design, a transparent n-layer and back contact play a key role to achieve high bifaciality. We therefore increased the transparency of the n-layer by adding CO2, increasing the PH3 flow in the deposition gas and tested different thicknesses. With those measures, we reached a bifaciality of 98% for short-circuit c.d. and 99% for open-circuit voltage.

Building energy performance evaluation of building integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) window with semi-transparent solar cells
Chae, Young Tae; Kim, Jeehwan; Park, Hongsik; Shin, Byungha

This study evaluates the effects of elec. and optical parameters of building integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows with a semi-transparent solar cell on the overall energy performance of a typical mid-sized com. building in various climate conditions. For precise evaluation of thermo-optical performance of the BIPV windows, we have fabricated semi-transparent amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells in various conditions and evaluated optical properties of the cells in addn. to the energy conversion efficiency. More importantly, we have taken optical parameters of the cells in different sun wavelength spectra on the front and back side of the cell because optical response at each wavelength affects differently on the energy conversion efficiency of the cell and thermal properties of BIPV windows. By using three different semi-transparent solar cell types, the annual whole building energy simulation was performed to evaluate the BIPV window performance in six different climate conditions. A significant change in the overall building energy consumption was obsd. by varying the thermo-optical characteristics of BIPV windows. Our results suggest it is required to customize the BIPV window characteristics with real optical data through sun wavelength spectra which is sensitively varying by the fabrication conditions of solar cells, in order to maximize building energy performance for different climate conditions at the building location.

Lim, Jung Wook; Shin, Myunghun; Lee, Da Jung; Lee, Seong Hyun; Yun, Sun Jin

We used very thin (i.e., ∼115-nm-thick) absorbers to fabricate full-penetration (FP) semitransparent a-Si:H solar cells for building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows and introduced high-bandgap (HB) n/i-interface layers to decrease shunt loss and increase carrier collection. The optoelectronic properties of the fabricated cells showed that the HB layers improved the fill factor by decreasing shunt loss and increased the short-circuit c.d. by enhancing generated-carrier collection. We used scattering matrix anal. to simulate the transmittance characteristics of the semitransparent solar cells fabricated using the HB layers and showed that the HB layers shifted the transmission peak to longer wavelengths. We used a figure of merit (FOM), the product of the efficiency and the av. transmittance in the range 400-800 nm, to represent the performance of the semitransparent solar cells and compared the FOMs of the cells fabricated for application to BIPV windows. The cell fabricated using triple HB layers showed the highest FOM, more than 20% higher efficiency than the ref. cell (fabricated without using any HB layers), and its transmittance was similar to that of the ref. cell. Fabricating FP semitransparent a-Si:H solar cells with triple HB layers and evaluating their optoelectronic performances will be very useful for implementing high-performance BIPV windows.

Chen, Wei; Wu, Yongzhen; Yue, Youfeng; Liu, Jian; Zhang, Wenjun; Yang, Xudong; Chen, Han; Bi, Enbing; Ashraful, Islam; Graetzel, Michael; Han, Liyuan

The recent dramatic rise in power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of perovskite solar cells (PSCs) has triggered intense research worldwide. However, high PCE values have often been reached with poor stability at an illuminated area of typically less than 0.1 square centimeter. We used heavily doped inorg. charge extn. layers in planar PSCs to achieve very rapid carrier extn., even with 10- to 20-nm-thick layers, avoiding pinholes and eliminating local structural defects over large areas. The robust inorg. nature of the layers allowed for the fabrication of PSCs with an aperture area >1 square centimeter that have a PCE >15%, as certified by an accredited photovoltaic calibration lab. Hysteresis in the current-voltage characteristics was eliminated; the PSCs were stable, with >90% of the initial PCE remaining after 1000 h of light soaking.

A contribution of counter electrode (CE) emphasis a great impact towards enhancement of a dye-sensitized solar cell's (DSSC) performance and Pt based CE sets a significant benchmark in this field. Owing to cost effective noble metal, less abundance and industrial large scale application purpose, an effective replacement for Pt is highly demanded. There are several approaches to improve the performance of a CE for enhancing the power conversion efficiency with a less costly and facile device. To address this issue, reasonable efforts execute to find out suitable replacement of Pt is becoming a challenge by keeping the same electrochem. properties of Pt in a cheaper and eco-friendlier manner. With this, cheaper element based quaternary chalcogenide, Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) becomes a prominent alternative to Pt and used as a successful CE in DSSC also. This review presents brief discussion about the basic properties of CZTS including its synthesis strategy, physicochem. properties and morphol. execution and ultimate application as an alternative Pt free CE for a low cost based enhanced DSSC device. It is therefore, imperative for engineering of CZTS material and optimization of the fabrication method for the improvement of DSSC performance. (c) 2018 American Institute of Physics.

Kim, Gayoung; Lim, Jung Wook; Shin, Myunghun; Yun, Sun Jin

Transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin-film solar cells, in which the colors of the front and rear faces can be adjusted individually, were developed for implementation in building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows. The proposed ultrathin transparent multilayered electrodes (TMEs) are highly conductive and transparent, consisting of a bottom layer of gallium-doped zinc oxide (GZO), a thin metal layer of Ag, and an optoelectronic controlling layer (OCL) of GZO. They can be used for both the front and rear electrodes of transparent a-Si:H solar cells, and the resulting solar cells show a 5.0% av. power conversion efficiency and 18.3% av. transmittance. The various dual colors on the front and rear of the cell can be individually adjusted by changing the thickness of the OCL on each face of the TME, without significantly changing the efficiency. The cell colors were quant. investigated using the color coordinates in a chromaticity diagram based on the International Commission on Illumination (CIE; 1931) std. to show that the simulated and obsd. colors match well under both LED and fluorescent light sources. We also show that the observable color of the BIPV windows is detd. by indoor and outdoor light sources, and dynamically varies as a function of illuminance of the light source as the day gradually progresses into night. This study helps to elucidate the color behavior of the BIPV windows and to develop a-Si:H BIPV windows that show various colors with stable elec. power generation.

We fabricated hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si: H) transparent solar cells using ultrathin transparent multi-layered electrodes (TMEs) as rear-side transparent electrodes for building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows. Each TME included a bottom layer, thin Ag layer, and optoelectronic controlling layer (OCL). The TMEs were exptl. designed to have high transparency and conductance. The fabricated a-Si:H transparent solar cells showed optimal performance with a 6.36% power-conversion efficiency and 23.5% av. transmittance (500-800 nm) when TMEs with a thickness less than 160 nm were incorporated. We demonstrated that the reflection color of the cell could be tuned without serious loss of cell efficiency by varying the thickness of the OCL. The backside colors were predicted to be the coordinates on a CIE 1931 chromaticity diagram using the reflection spectrum from the cell and emission spectrum of a 50 W LED light source. The developed a-Si:H transparent solar cells exhibited high efficiency and show feasibility for incorporating various colors in the photovoltaic and aesthetic functionalities of BIPV windows.

Low-Temperature Plasma-Assisted Atomic Layer Deposition of Silicon Nitride Moisture Permeation Barrier Layers
Andringa, Anne-Marije; Perrotta, Alberto; de Peuter, Koen; Knoops, Harm C. M.; Kessels, Wilhelmus M. M.; Creatore, Mariadriana
ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces
(
2015
),
7
(
40
),
22525-22532
CODEN:
AAMICK
; ISSN:
1944-8244
.
(
American Chemical Society

Encapsulation of org. (opto-)electronic devices, such as org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), photovoltaic cells, and field-effect transistors, is required to minimize device degrdn. induced by moisture and oxygen ingress. SiNx moisture permeation barriers were fabricated using a very recently developed low-temp. plasma-assisted at. layer deposition (ALD) approach, consisting of half-reactions of the substrate with the precursor SiH2(NHtBu)2 and with N2-fed plasma. The deposited films were characterized in terms of their refractive index and chem. compn. by spectroscopic ellipsometry (SE), XPS, and FTIR spectroscopy. The SiNx thin-film refractive index ranges from 1.80 to 1.90 for films deposited at 80° up to 200°, resp., and the C, O, and H impurity levels decrease when the deposition temp. increases. The relative open porosity content of the layers was studied by multisolvent ellipsometric porosimetry (EP), adopting three solvents with different kinetic diams.: water (∼0.3 nm), ethanol (∼0.4 nm), and toluene (∼0.6 nm). Irresp. of the deposition temp., and hence the impurity content in the SiNx films, no uptake of any adsorptive was obsd., pointing to the absence of open pores larger than 0.3 nm in diam. Instead, multilayer development was obsd., leading to II isotherms that, according to the IUPAC classification, are characteristic of nonporous layers. The calcium test was performed in a climate chamber at 20° and 50% relative humidity to det. the intrinsic water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of SiNx barriers deposited at 120°. Intrinsic WVTR values in the range of 10-6 g/m2/day indicate excellent barrier properties for ALD SiNx layers as thin as 10 nm, competing with that of state-of-the-art plasma-enhanced chem. vapor-deposited SiNx layers of a few hundred nanometers in thickness.

The effect of argon plasma treatment on the permeation barrier properties of silicon nitride layers
Majee, S.; Cerqueira, M. F.; Tondelier, D.; Geffroy, B.; Bonnassieux, Y.; Alpuim, P.; Bouree, J. E.

In this work we produce and study silicon nitride (SiNx) thin films deposited by Hot Wire Chem. Vapor Deposition (HW-CVD) to be used as encapsulation barriers for flexible org. photovoltaic cells fabricated on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrates in order to increase their shelf lifetime. We report on the results of SiNx double-layers and on the equiv. double-layer stack where an Ar-plasma surface treatment was performed on the first SiNx layer. The Ar-plasma treatment may under certain conditions influences the structure of the interface between the two subsequent layers and thus the barrier properties of the whole system. We focus our attention on the effect of plasma treatment time on the final barrier properties. We assess the encapsulation barrier properties of these layers, using the calcium degrdn. test where changes in the elec. conductance of encapsulated Ca sensors are monitored with time. The water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) is found to be ∼ 3 × 10-3 g/m2·day for stacked SiNx double-layer with 8 min Ar plasma surface treatment.

Dingemans, Gijs; Kessels, Erwin

A review. The redn. in electronic recombination losses by the passivation of silicon surfaces is a crit. enabler for high-efficiency solar cells. In 2006, aluminum oxide (Al2O3) nanolayers synthesized by at. layer deposition (ALD) emerged as a novel soln. for the passivation of p- and n-type cryst. Si (c-Si) surfaces. Today, high efficiencies have been realized by the implementation of ultrathin Al2O3 films in lab.-type and industrial solar cells. This article reviews and summarizes recent work concerning Al2O3 thin films in the context of Si photovoltaics. Topics range from fundamental aspects related to material, interface, and passivation properties to synthesis methods and the implementation of the films in solar cells. Al2O3 uniquely features a combination of field-effect passivation by neg. fixed charges, a low interface defect d., an adequate stability during processing, and the ability to use ultrathin films down to a few nanometers in thickness. Although various methods can be used to synthesize Al2O3, this review focuses on ALD-a new technol. in the field of c-Si photovoltaics. The authors discuss how the unique features of ALD can be exploited for interface engineering and tailoring the properties of nanolayer surface passivation schemes while also addressing its compatibility with high-throughput manufg. The recent progress achieved in the field of surface passivation allows for higher efficiencies of industrial solar cells, which is crit. for realizing lower-cost solar electricity in the near future. Thin films of Al2O3 grown by at. layer deposition (ALD) were investigated as gas diffusion barriers on flexible polyethylene naphthalate and Kapton polyimide substrates. Al2O3 ALD films with thicknesses of 1-26 nm were grown at 100°-175°. For Al2O3 ALD films with thicknesses ≥5 nm, oxygen transmission rates were below the MOCON instrument test limit of ∼5 × 10-3 cc/m2/day. Applying a more sensitive radioactive tracer method, H2O-vapor transmission rates of ∼1 × 10-3 g/m2/day were measured for single-sided Al2O3 ALD films with thicknesses of 26 nm on the polymers. Ultrathin gas diffusion barriers grown by Al2O3 ALD may enable org. displays and electronics on permeable, flexible polymer substrates.

Definition of encapsulation barrier requirements: A method applied to organic solar cells
Cros, S.; de Bettignies, R.; Berson, S.; Bailly, S.; Maisse, P.; Lemaitre, N.; Guillerez, S.

To reach sufficient lifetime for com. applications, org. solar cells (OPV) require encapsulation with a low permeability barrier material toward atm. oxidizing agents, specifically water. Moreover, barrier materials should have the same driving aspects as org. devices like transparency, flexibility and low cost processing techniques such as coating or lamination. The generally admitted value of 10-6 g m-2 day-1 for water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) derived from OLED technol. should not be considered as an applicable golden rule and some recent studies demonstrate that OPV cells can be protected with medium barrier materials with a WVTR of around 10-3 g-m-2 day-1. This improved stability is mainly related to the development of new cell architectures. However, a global barrier requirement cannot be defined, but has to be on one hand established in direct relationship between intrinsic stability of the device and on the other hand on the targeted lifetime and operating conditions. In this study, we applied a method to define rapidly the barrier requirement of two OPV cell types named classical and inverted structures. This method combines barrier measurements of encapsulating materials with accelerated lifetime expts. of encapsulated cells and enables to establish the barrier levels necessary to ensure the protection of a given device depending on the intrinsic stability and targeted lifetime.

Degradation by water vapor of hydrogenated amorphous silicon oxynitride films grown at low temperature
Lee Hyung-Ik; Park Jong-Bong; Xianyu Wenxu; Kim Kihong; Chung Jae Gwan; Kyoung Yong Koo; Byun Sunjung; Yang Woo Young; Park Yong Young; Kim Seong Min; Cho Eunae; Shin Jai Kwang
Scientific reports
(
2017
),
7
(
1
),
14146
ISSN:
.
We report on the degradation process by water vapor of hydrogenated amorphous silicon oxynitride (SiON:H) films deposited by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition at low temperature. The stability of the films was investigated as a function of the oxygen content and deposition temperature. Degradation by defects such as pinholes was not observed with transmission electron microscopy. However, we observed that SiON:H film degrades by reacting with water vapor through only interstitial paths and nano-defects. To monitor the degradation process, the atomic composition, mass density, and fully oxidized thickness were measured by using high-resolution Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy and X-ray reflectometry. The film rapidly degraded above an oxygen composition of ~27 at%, below a deposition temperature of ~150 °C, and below an mass density of ~2.15 g/cm(3). This trend can be explained by the extents of porosity and percolation channel based on the ring model of the network structure. In the case of a high oxygen composition or low temperature, the SiON:H film becomes more porous because the film consists of network channels of rings with a low energy barrier.

Amorphous single-junction cells for vertical BIPV application with high bifaciality
Reininghaus, Nies; Feser, Clemens; Hanke, Benedikt; Vehse, Martin; Agert, Carsten
Energy Science & Engineering
(

CODEN:

2050-0505

(
John Wiley & Sons Ltd.
)
Solar cells used in building integration of photovoltaic cells (BIPV) are commonly made from cryst. wafer cells. This contribution investigates the challenges and benefits of using bifacial solar cells in vertical installations. We show that those cells get up to 13% more irradiance compared to optimum tilted south facing monofacial modules in Germany. The role of the n-layer in thin amorphous bifacial single-junction cells intended to be used as bifacial cells in BIPV applications is investigated. In contrast to the superstrate cell design, a transparent n-layer and back contact play a key role to achieve high bifaciality. We therefore increased the transparency of the n-layer by adding CO2, increasing the PH3 flow in the deposition gas and tested different thicknesses. With those measures, we reached a bifaciality of 98% for short-circuit c.d. and 99% for open-circuit voltage.

Building energy performance evaluation of building integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) window with semi-transparent solar cells
Chae, Young Tae; Kim, Jeehwan; Park, Hongsik; Shin, Byungha
Applied Energy
(

This study evaluates the effects of elec. and optical parameters of building integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows with a semi-transparent solar cell on the overall energy performance of a typical mid-sized com. building in various climate conditions. For precise evaluation of thermo-optical performance of the BIPV windows, we have fabricated semi-transparent amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) solar cells in various conditions and evaluated optical properties of the cells in addn. to the energy conversion efficiency. More importantly, we have taken optical parameters of the cells in different sun wavelength spectra on the front and back side of the cell because optical response at each wavelength affects differently on the energy conversion efficiency of the cell and thermal properties of BIPV windows. By using three different semi-transparent solar cell types, the annual whole building energy simulation was performed to evaluate the BIPV window performance in six different climate conditions. A significant change in the overall building energy consumption was obsd. by varying the thermo-optical characteristics of BIPV windows. Our results suggest it is required to customize the BIPV window characteristics with real optical data through sun wavelength spectra which is sensitively varying by the fabrication conditions of solar cells, in order to maximize building energy performance for different climate conditions at the building location.

Lim, Jung Wook; Shin, Myunghun; Lee, Da Jung; Lee, Seong Hyun; Yun, Sun Jin

We used very thin (i.e., ∼115-nm-thick) absorbers to fabricate full-penetration (FP) semitransparent a-Si:H solar cells for building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows and introduced high-bandgap (HB) n/i-interface layers to decrease shunt loss and increase carrier collection. The optoelectronic properties of the fabricated cells showed that the HB layers improved the fill factor by decreasing shunt loss and increased the short-circuit c.d. by enhancing generated-carrier collection. We used scattering matrix anal. to simulate the transmittance characteristics of the semitransparent solar cells fabricated using the HB layers and showed that the HB layers shifted the transmission peak to longer wavelengths. We used a figure of merit (FOM), the product of the efficiency and the av. transmittance in the range 400-800 nm, to represent the performance of the semitransparent solar cells and compared the FOMs of the cells fabricated for application to BIPV windows. The cell fabricated using triple HB layers showed the highest FOM, more than 20% higher efficiency than the ref. cell (fabricated without using any HB layers), and its transmittance was similar to that of the ref. cell. Fabricating FP semitransparent a-Si:H solar cells with triple HB layers and evaluating their optoelectronic performances will be very useful for implementing high-performance BIPV windows.

The recent dramatic rise in power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of perovskite solar cells (PSCs) has triggered intense research worldwide. However, high PCE values have often been reached with poor stability at an illuminated area of typically less than 0.1 square centimeter. We used heavily doped inorg. charge extn. layers in planar PSCs to achieve very rapid carrier extn., even with 10- to 20-nm-thick layers, avoiding pinholes and eliminating local structural defects over large areas. The robust inorg. nature of the layers allowed for the fabrication of PSCs with an aperture area >1 square centimeter that have a PCE >15%, as certified by an accredited photovoltaic calibration lab. Hysteresis in the current-voltage characteristics was eliminated; the PSCs were stable, with >90% of the initial PCE remaining after 1000 h of light soaking.

A contribution of counter electrode (CE) emphasis a great impact towards enhancement of a dye-sensitized solar cell's (DSSC) performance and Pt based CE sets a significant benchmark in this field. Owing to cost effective noble metal, less abundance and industrial large scale application purpose, an effective replacement for Pt is highly demanded. There are several approaches to improve the performance of a CE for enhancing the power conversion efficiency with a less costly and facile device. To address this issue, reasonable efforts execute to find out suitable replacement of Pt is becoming a challenge by keeping the same electrochem. properties of Pt in a cheaper and eco-friendlier manner. With this, cheaper element based quaternary chalcogenide, Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) becomes a prominent alternative to Pt and used as a successful CE in DSSC also. This review presents brief discussion about the basic properties of CZTS including its synthesis strategy, physicochem. properties and morphol. execution and ultimate application as an alternative Pt free CE for a low cost based enhanced DSSC device. It is therefore, imperative for engineering of CZTS material and optimization of the fabrication method for the improvement of DSSC performance. (c) 2018 American Institute of Physics.

Transparent hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin-film solar cells, in which the colors of the front and rear faces can be adjusted individually, were developed for implementation in building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows. The proposed ultrathin transparent multilayered electrodes (TMEs) are highly conductive and transparent, consisting of a bottom layer of gallium-doped zinc oxide (GZO), a thin metal layer of Ag, and an optoelectronic controlling layer (OCL) of GZO. They can be used for both the front and rear electrodes of transparent a-Si:H solar cells, and the resulting solar cells show a 5.0% av. power conversion efficiency and 18.3% av. transmittance. The various dual colors on the front and rear of the cell can be individually adjusted by changing the thickness of the OCL on each face of the TME, without significantly changing the efficiency. The cell colors were quant. investigated using the color coordinates in a chromaticity diagram based on the International Commission on Illumination (CIE; 1931) std. to show that the simulated and obsd. colors match well under both LED and fluorescent light sources. We also show that the observable color of the BIPV windows is detd. by indoor and outdoor light sources, and dynamically varies as a function of illuminance of the light source as the day gradually progresses into night. This study helps to elucidate the color behavior of the BIPV windows and to develop a-Si:H BIPV windows that show various colors with stable elec. power generation.

We fabricated hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si: H) transparent solar cells using ultrathin transparent multi-layered electrodes (TMEs) as rear-side transparent electrodes for building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) windows. Each TME included a bottom layer, thin Ag layer, and optoelectronic controlling layer (OCL). The TMEs were exptl. designed to have high transparency and conductance. The fabricated a-Si:H transparent solar cells showed optimal performance with a 6.36% power-conversion efficiency and 23.5% av. transmittance (500-800 nm) when TMEs with a thickness less than 160 nm were incorporated. We demonstrated that the reflection color of the cell could be tuned without serious loss of cell efficiency by varying the thickness of the OCL. The backside colors were predicted to be the coordinates on a CIE 1931 chromaticity diagram using the reflection spectrum from the cell and emission spectrum of a 50 W LED light source. The developed a-Si:H transparent solar cells exhibited high efficiency and show feasibility for incorporating various colors in the photovoltaic and aesthetic functionalities of BIPV windows.

Encapsulation of org. (opto-)electronic devices, such as org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), photovoltaic cells, and field-effect transistors, is required to minimize device degrdn. induced by moisture and oxygen ingress. SiNx moisture permeation barriers were fabricated using a very recently developed low-temp. plasma-assisted at. layer deposition (ALD) approach, consisting of half-reactions of the substrate with the precursor SiH2(NHtBu)2 and with N2-fed plasma. The deposited films were characterized in terms of their refractive index and chem. compn. by spectroscopic ellipsometry (SE), XPS, and FTIR spectroscopy. The SiNx thin-film refractive index ranges from 1.80 to 1.90 for films deposited at 80° up to 200°, resp., and the C, O, and H impurity levels decrease when the deposition temp. increases. The relative open porosity content of the layers was studied by multisolvent ellipsometric porosimetry (EP), adopting three solvents with different kinetic diams.: water (∼0.3 nm), ethanol (∼0.4 nm), and toluene (∼0.6 nm). Irresp. of the deposition temp., and hence the impurity content in the SiNx films, no uptake of any adsorptive was obsd., pointing to the absence of open pores larger than 0.3 nm in diam. Instead, multilayer development was obsd., leading to II isotherms that, according to the IUPAC classification, are characteristic of nonporous layers. The calcium test was performed in a climate chamber at 20° and 50% relative humidity to det. the intrinsic water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of SiNx barriers deposited at 120°. Intrinsic WVTR values in the range of 10-6 g/m2/day indicate excellent barrier properties for ALD SiNx layers as thin as 10 nm, competing with that of state-of-the-art plasma-enhanced chem. vapor-deposited SiNx layers of a few hundred nanometers in thickness.

In this work we produce and study silicon nitride (SiNx) thin films deposited by Hot Wire Chem. Vapor Deposition (HW-CVD) to be used as encapsulation barriers for flexible org. photovoltaic cells fabricated on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrates in order to increase their shelf lifetime. We report on the results of SiNx double-layers and on the equiv. double-layer stack where an Ar-plasma surface treatment was performed on the first SiNx layer. The Ar-plasma treatment may under certain conditions influences the structure of the interface between the two subsequent layers and thus the barrier properties of the whole system. We focus our attention on the effect of plasma treatment time on the final barrier properties. We assess the encapsulation barrier properties of these layers, using the calcium degrdn. test where changes in the elec. conductance of encapsulated Ca sensors are monitored with time. The water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) is found to be ∼ 3 × 10-3 g/m2·day for stacked SiNx double-layer with 8 min Ar plasma surface treatment.

A review. The redn. in electronic recombination losses by the passivation of silicon surfaces is a crit. enabler for high-efficiency solar cells. In 2006, aluminum oxide (Al2O3) nanolayers synthesized by at. layer deposition (ALD) emerged as a novel soln. for the passivation of p- and n-type cryst. Si (c-Si) surfaces. Today, high efficiencies have been realized by the implementation of ultrathin Al2O3 films in lab.-type and industrial solar cells. This article reviews and summarizes recent work concerning Al2O3 thin films in the context of Si photovoltaics. Topics range from fundamental aspects related to material, interface, and passivation properties to synthesis methods and the implementation of the films in solar cells. Al2O3 uniquely features a combination of field-effect passivation by neg. fixed charges, a low interface defect d., an adequate stability during processing, and the ability to use ultrathin films down to a few nanometers in thickness. Although various methods can be used to synthesize Al2O3, this review focuses on ALD-a new technol. in the field of c-Si photovoltaics. The authors discuss how the unique features of ALD can be exploited for interface engineering and tailoring the properties of nanolayer surface passivation schemes while also addressing its compatibility with high-throughput manufg. The recent progress achieved in the field of surface passivation allows for higher efficiencies of industrial solar cells, which is crit. for realizing lower-cost solar electricity in the near future. To reach sufficient lifetime for com. applications, org. solar cells (OPV) require encapsulation with a low permeability barrier material toward atm. oxidizing agents, specifically water. Moreover, barrier materials should have the same driving aspects as org. devices like transparency, flexibility and low cost processing techniques such as coating or lamination. The generally admitted value of 10-6 g m-2 day-1 for water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) derived from OLED technol. should not be considered as an applicable golden rule and some recent studies demonstrate that OPV cells can be protected with medium barrier materials with a WVTR of around 10-3 g-m-2 day-1. This improved stability is mainly related to the development of new cell architectures. However, a global barrier requirement cannot be defined, but has to be on one hand established in direct relationship between intrinsic stability of the device and on the other hand on the targeted lifetime and operating conditions. In this study, we applied a method to define rapidly the barrier requirement of two OPV cell types named classical and inverted structures. This method combines barrier measurements of encapsulating materials with accelerated lifetime expts. of encapsulated cells and enables to establish the barrier levels necessary to ensure the protection of a given device depending on the intrinsic stability and targeted lifetime.

Degradation by water vapor of hydrogenated amorphous silicon oxynitride films grown at low temperature
Lee Hyung-Ik; Park Jong-Bong; Xianyu Wenxu; Kim Kihong; Chung Jae Gwan; Kyoung Yong Koo; Byun Sunjung; Yang Woo Young; Park Yong Young; Kim Seong Min; Cho Eunae; Shin Jai Kwang

.
We report on the degradation process by water vapor of hydrogenated amorphous silicon oxynitride (SiON:H) films deposited by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition at low temperature. The stability of the films was investigated as a function of the oxygen content and deposition temperature. Degradation by defects such as pinholes was not observed with transmission electron microscopy. However, we observed that SiON:H film degrades by reacting with water vapor through only interstitial paths and nano-defects. To monitor the degradation process, the atomic composition, mass density, and fully oxidized thickness were measured by using high-resolution Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy and X-ray reflectometry. The film rapidly degraded above an oxygen composition of ~27 at%, below a deposition temperature of ~150 °C, and below an mass density of ~2.15 g/cm(3). This trend can be explained by the extents of porosity and percolation channel based on the ring model of the network structure. In the case of a high oxygen composition or low temperature, the SiON:H film becomes more porous because the film consists of network channels of rings with a low energy barrier.
